title: Stellar Mofo line-up announced
text:
Stellar line-up announced for Mofo 2016 by: What are these? Mofo curator Brian Ritchie has planned a stellar line-up for 2016. Picture: KIM EISZELE Source: News Limited Drummers Maggie Abraham, left, and Tracey Pattern make a bit of a splash under bit.fall (Mona’s iconic waterfall) at today’s Mofo launch. Picture: KIM EISZELE Source: News Limited 
ARTISTS including Australian singer Kate Miller-Heidke, Japanese DJ Krush and American composer Antonio Sánchez will play next year’s Museum of Old and New Art’s Festival of Music and Art, Mofo, from January 13-18. 
They will join already announced American psychedelic rock band The Flaming Lips , who will play on the outdoor Mona Main Stage. 
The festival will move away from its traditional hub on Hobart’s waterfront, Princes Wharf 1, and will centre around the Berriedale museum as well as other venues and exhibition spaces around Hobart. 
More than 300 artists were announced to play the festival at a media event at Mona today, featuring drummers playing under art instalment bit.fall. 
End of sidebar. Return to start of sidebar. 
Curated by Brian Ritchie, Mofo 2016 will feature musicians, and performers from around the world including percussionist Evelyn Glennie (UK) at the Federation Concert Hall; award-winning composer Antonio Sánchez (USA) performing his original drums-only score to a screening of the Academy Award-winning film Birdman; Japanese hip hop turntablist pioneer DJ Krush; Norwegian art-pop provocateur Jenny Hval, award-winning British poet-turned-rapper Kate Tempest and more, from as far afield as Ethiopia, Norway, Japan and Belgium. Mofo 2016 line-up announced 
Mofo challenges artists to commit new collaborations, with Kate Miller-Heidke debuting new works with the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra (TSO) at the Odeon Theatre. 
Three dark plays by the renowned playwright, Samuel Beckett – Footfalls, Eh Joe, and Krapp’s Last Tape – will be presented in a Beckett Triptych, performed by State Theatre Company of South Australia at the Theatre Royal. 
The whole Mona site will be closed to the general public between 15-17 January, with only ticket-holders granted entry to experience Mona’s offerings as well as the major retrospective Gilbert & George. 
MoMa (Mona market) returns for the three-day weekend at Mona and continues weekly on Sundays until March 27. 
Mofo events and exhibitions will also be held around Hobart, at the Federation Concert Hall, Rosny Barn, Moonah Arts Centre, Salamanca Arts Centre’s Peacock Theatre and Kelly’s Garden, Contemporary Arts Tasmania, Brooke Street Pier and at Alonnah Hall on Bruny Island. 
Mofo runs 13-18 January 2016. Tickets are on sale now from www.mofo.net.au
